pullRequest.body:
Shows that in relational languages, all sets are closed as substructures.
As a consequence, finiteness is the same as finite generation.

---

bors d+

`x.closed` is a set not a function
```suggestion
lemma mem_closed_iff (s : Set M) :
    s âˆˆ (closure L).closed â†” âˆ€ {n}, âˆ€ f : L.Functions n, ClosedUnder f s := by
```
which hould also remove the need for the `change`
Should also use `mem` here

```suggestion
  Â· have h' : closure L s = âŸ¨s, hâŸ© := closure_eq_of_le (refl _) subset_closure
    exact congr_arg _ h'
```

```suggestion
lemma mem_closed_of_isRelational [L.IsRelational] (s : Set M) : s âˆˆ (closure L).closed :=
```
Can we have `fg_iff_finite`? Same below

```suggestion
theorem FG.of_finite {s : L.Substructure M} [h : Finite s] : s.FG :=
```
this will allow dot-notation

```suggestion
theorem FG.finite [L.IsRelational] {S : L.Substructure M} (h : S.FG) : Finite S := by
```
Idem

```suggestion
theorem FG.of_finite [Finite M] : FG L M := by
```

```suggestion
theorem FG.finite [L.IsRelational] (h : FG L M) : Finite M :=
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(ModelTheory): Substructure-closure and finite generation in relational languages
